{{Infobox recurring event | name = United Nations Climate Change Conference | image = COP19-CMP9 (11034852064).jpg | begins = 11 November 2013 | ends = 23 November 2013 | venue = [[National Stadium, Warsaw|Poland National Stadium]] | location = [[Warsaw]] | country = [[Poland]] | genre = Conferences | prev = [[2012 United Nations Climate Change Conference|2012]] | next = [[2014 United Nations Climate Change Conference|2014]] | website = www.cop19.gov.pl }}
[[File:COP19 opening (22).JPG|thumb|300px|Opening of the COP19 on 11 November 2013]]
The '''United Nations Climate Change Conference''', '''COP19''' or '''CMP9''' was held in [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]] from 11 to 23 November 2013. This is the 19th yearly session of the Conference of the Parties (COP 19) to the 1992 [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC) and the 9th session of the Meeting of the Parties (CMP 9) to the 1997 [[Kyoto Protocol]].<ref>{{cite web|title=19th Session of the Conference of the Parties to the UNFCCC|url=http://climate-l.iisd.org/events/conference-of-the-parties-to-the-unfccc/|publisher=[[International Institute for Sustainable Development]]|accessdate=20 February 2013}}</ref> The conference delegates continue the negotiations towards a global climate agreement. UNFCCC's Executive Secretary [[Christiana Figueres]] and [[Ministry of Environment (Poland)|Poland's Minister]] of the Environment [[Marcin Korolec]] led the negotiations.
The conference led to an agreement that all states would start cutting emissions as soon as possible, but preferably by the first quarter of 2015. The '''Warsaw Mechanism''' was also proposed.
==Background== Several preliminary and actual agreements were at the forefront of the talks, including: unused credits from phase one of the [[Kyoto Protocol]], improvements to several UNFCCC action mechanisms, and a refinement of the measurement, reporting, and verification of [[greenhouse gas]] emissions (GHGs).<ref name=ICT>{{cite web|title=Bridges Warsaw update: Financing key to unlocking progress at COP 19|url=http://ictsd.org/i/news/bioresreview/178642/|publisher=International Centre for Trade and Sustainable Development|accessdate=12 November 2013}}</ref> Delegates are to focus on the potential conditions of a final global [[climate change]] agreement expected to be ratified in 2015 at the Paris Conference.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cienski|first=Jan|title=Leaders Gather in Warsaw for Climate Change Negotiations|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/cc10f728-4abf-11e3-8c4c-00144feabdc0,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2Fcc10f728-4abf-11e3-8c4c-00144feabdc0.html%3Fsiteedition%3Dintl&siteedition=intl&_i_referer=|accessdate=12 November 2013|newspaper=The Financial Times UK|date=11 November 2013}}</ref>
==Location and participation== [[File:Stadion Narodowy w Warszawie 20120422.jpg|thumb|The [[National Stadium, Warsaw|National Stadium]] in Warsaw, the main venue of the conference]]
The location of UNFCCC talks are rotated by regions throughout [[United Nations]] countries. In 2013 Warsaw, the capital and largest city in Poland, was chosen to represent the Eastern European Group in the COP 19 Presidency.<ref>{{cite web|title=Incoming Polish Presidency of the 19th Conference of the Parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change|url=http://www.cop19.gov.pl/incoming-polish-presidency-of-cop19-cmp9|publisher=United Nations Climate Change Forum|accessdate=12 November 2013}}</ref>
The choice of Poland has been criticised by environmental organizations, including [[Greenpeace]], because of the country's lack of commitment to reduce its use of fossil fuels and increase use of [[renewable energy]]. As of 2013, 88% of [[Energy in Poland|Poland's electricity]] is sourced from coal, as compared to the global average of 68% electricity from fossil fuels.<ref>{{cite book|title=Key World Energy Statistics|year=2013|publisher=International Energy Agency|location=Paris|page=24|url=http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyWorld2013_FINAL_WEB.pdf}}</ref> Its officials have been blocking EU proposals to more effectively act against global warming. Standing alone against the other [[Member state of the European Union|EU member states]], in 2011 Poland blocked the proposed emission targets for 2050, and its environment minister [[Marcin Korolec]] (president of the conference) declared himself sceptical about the EU's strategy of leading by example.<ref>Hakim, Danny and Mateusz Zurawik: [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/01/business/energy-environment/poland-wedded-to-coal-spurns-europe-on-clean-energy.html "Poland, Wedded to Coal, Spurns Europe on Clean Energy Targets"], in ''[[The New York Times]]'', 31 October 2013</ref>
Over 10,000 participants from 189 countries registered to attend the conference, but only 134 ministers announced participation. Four countries that are among the most vulnerable to climate change were represented by their president or prime minister: [[Tuvalu]], [[Nauru]], [[Ethiopia]] and [[Tanzania]].<ref>Yeo, Sophie: [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/nov/13/warsaw-climate-talks-countries-ministers "Warsaw climate talks: nearly 3 in 10 countries not sending ministers"], in ''[[The Guardian]]'', 14 November 2013</ref> <Ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cop19.gov.pl/latest-news/items/statement-of-president-of-cop19-minister-marcin-korolec-on-the-participation-of-ngos-in-the-climate-summit|title=Statement of President of COP19 Minister Marcin Korolec on the participation of NGOs in the Climate Summit - COP19 - CMP9, Conference of Parties and climate change conference|first=Agencja Interaktywna|last=Migomedia|website=www.cop19.gov.pl}}</ref> Polish Prime Minister [[Donald Tusk]] dismissed Korolec in preference for a politician who would be better able to deliver a "radical acceleration of shale gas operations" in the country. However, he said that Korolec would remain the government's plenipotentiary for the conference.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/environment/planet-oz/2013/nov/21/warsaw-climate-change-conference-global-warming|title=Warsaw's widening climate chasm could lead to 4C warming - Graham Readfearn|first=Graham|last=Readfearn|date=21 November 2013|website=the Guardian}}</ref>
==Negotiations== The overarching goal of the conference is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs) to limit the global temperature increase to 2 degrees Celsius above current levels.<ref>{{cite web|title=Schedule of Events |url=http://unfccc.int/files/meetings/warsaw_nov_2013/application/pdf/cop19cmp9_overview_schedule.pdf |publisher=United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change |accessdate=12 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112055835/http://unfccc.int/files/meetings/warsaw_nov_2013/application/pdf/cop19cmp9_overview_schedule.pdf |archivedate=12 November 2013 }}</ref> According to the Executive Secretary of the UNFCCC, Christiana Figueres, :“Global greenhouse gas emissions need to peak this decade, and get to zero net emissions by the second half of this century... National governments need to act to minimize impacts to their populations and ensure sustainable development over generations. The private sector needs to act to minimize climate risk and capture opportunity. And the international process must push forward now to build the foundation for an ambitious universal climate change agreement in 2015,”<ref name="auto">{{cite web|title=UNFCCC: Warsaw COP "pivotal moment to step up climate action"|url=http://cleantech.cleantechpoland.com/?page=news&id=113&link=unfccc-warsaw-cop-pivotal-moment-to-step-up-climate-action-|publisher=Clean Tech Poland|accessdate=12 November 2013}}</ref>
Clean energy, and specifically the financing and technology transfer of renewables in developing countries, will be of main importance during the conference. The Indian Minister of the Environment stated before the talks that “the most important milestone would be climate finance and capitalisation of the [[Green Climate Fund]] (GCF), which has not happened at all... Developed countries that made a commitment earlier have now started talking of alternative sources of funding - whereas in our view these are commitments of the parties to the COP.”<ref name=ICT/> Agreements in the Copenhagen round ostensibly formalized $US 100 billion to the Clean Energy Fund by 2020 to assist developing countries in energy development, whereas only $US 7.5 million had been committed as of June 2013.<ref name=ICT/> Australia has support from Britain and others to head off demands for compensation payments to countries hit by damage they blame on climate change, sparking anger at a global summit meant to strike a deal this weekend. Acting on [[Tony Abbott]]’s edict to avoid any new financial commitments, Australian negotiators have held out against calls to support the “loss and damage” payments sought by poorer countries
Technology transfer and sharing of [[intellectual property]] between industrialised and developing countries will be a major concern in the Warsaw talks.<ref name="auto"/> Historically, these discussions have been stalled due to disagreements over the price and sharing mechanisms surrounding intellectual property, and thus new approaches are expected in the Warsaw conference.<ref name=ICT/>
A stalemate surrounding the talks has been the insistence of the United States delegates on China and India conforming to binding reduction commitments - whereas Chinese and Indian delegates argue that funding from industrialised countries is needed before such emissions cuts can be executed without impacting [[GDP]] growth rates.<ref name=ICT/> India and Saudi Arabia blocked an agreement which could prevent the release of up to 100 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions by 2050. A key paragraph in a draft resolution that would have accelerated international cooperation under the [[Montreal Protocol]] was reportedly deleted at the last minute.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theecologist.org/News/news_round_up/2170299/cop19_india_and_saudi_arabia_join_the_climate_saboteurs.html|title=COP19 - India and Saudi Arabia join the 'Climate Saboteurs'|publisher=}}</ref>
The deaths, injuries and destruction caused by [[Typhoon Haiyan]] were brought to attention during the opening day talks. In response to the typhoon and to climate change damage in general, [[Naderev Saño|Naderev "Yeb" Saño]], the lead negotiator of the Philippines delegation, received a standing ovation for announcing: {{cquote|In solidarity with my countrymen who are struggling to find food back home, I will now commence a voluntary fasting for the climate, this means I will voluntarily refrain from eating food during this COP, until a meaningful outcome is in sight.|author=Naderev Saño|source=speaking at the 2013 United Nations Climate Change Conference<ref>{{cite news|last=McGrath|first=Matt|title=Typhoon prompts 'fast' by Philippines climate delegate|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-24899647|accessdate=12 November 2013|newspaper=BBC|date=11 November 2013}}</ref>}}
On 21 November, the first Cities and Sub-national Dialogue took place. This consisted of selected ministers, mayors and sub-national leaders and civil society representatives discussing mitigation and adaptation at a local scale.<Ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cop19.gov.pl/latest-news/items/city-mayors-and-regional-leaders-discuss-at-cop19cmp9|title=City mayors and regional leaders discuss at COP19/CMP9 - COP19 - CMP9, Conference of Parties and climate change conference|first=Agencja Interaktywna|last=Migomedia|website=www.cop19.gov.pl}}</ref>
===Walkouts===
The G77 and China bloc led 132 poor countries in a walk out during talks about “loss and damage” compensation for the consequences of global warming. Poor countries have demanded that the developed world give them $100 billion annually by 2020. Activists and poor countries accused Australian diplomats of not taking the talks seriously. The country did not send high-ranking officials to the UN summit, saying that they would be busy repealing the country’s contentious carbon tax. ''The carbon tax is bad for the economy and it doesn’t do any good for the environment,'' Prime Minister Tony Abbott told The Washington Post. ''Despite a carbon tax of $37 a ton by 2020, Australia’s domestic emissions were going up, not down. The carbon tax was basically socialism masquerading as environmentalism, and that’s why it’s going to get abolished.''
On the last day of the conference [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]], [[Oxfam]], [[ActionAid]], the [[International Trade Union Confederation]], [[Friends of the Earth]] and [[Greenpeace]] walked out of the conference. Greenpeace spokesman Gregor Kessler, however, said that they would not leave the city but would "follow the discussions from the outside. We will not be part of the internal discussions." Oxfam' Executive Director Winnie Byanyima said: "[Governments] must...come back in 2014 ready for meaningful discussions on how they will deliver their share of the emissions reductions which scientists say are needed and their share of the money needed to help the poorest and most vulnerable countries adapt." All six issued a statement that read: "Organisations and movements representing people from every corner of the Earth have decided that the best use of our time is to voluntarily withdraw from the Warsaw climate talks. The Warsaw climate conference, which should have been an important step in the just transition to a sustainable future, is on track to deliver virtually nothing."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2013/11/green-groups-walk-out-un-climate-talks-2013112115105648189.html|title=Green groups walk out of UN climate talks|website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref>
===Conclusion=== The conference ran beyond the scheduled end date of 22 November by a day<Ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2013/11/climate-summit-overtime-due-deadlock-201311234643975109.html|title=Climate summit in overtime due to deadlock|website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref> before some consensus was reached. Member states agreed to work towards curbing emissions as soon as possible, with an idea date targeted at the first quarter of 2015.
Talk however continued on the aid that developed countries would pay to help emissions cuts by developing countries. Having previously promised US$100 billion a year after 2020 from the US$10 billion a year between 2010-2012, they resisted calls to set targets for the rest of the decade. The draft resolution of the conference, though, only mentioned setting "increasing levels" of aid. Further the '''Warsaw Mechanism''' was proposed, which would provide expertise, and possibly aid, to developing nations to cope with loss and damage from such natural extremities as heatwaves, droughts and floods and threats such as rising sea levels and desertification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2013/11/deadlock-broken-at-un-climate-talks-20131123163641928770.html|title=Deadlock broken at UN climate talks|website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref>
==Criticism== ===Organisers=== The organizers of COP19 were strongly criticised for posting comments in an online blog in the lead-up to the conference about the purported advantages of [[Climate change in the Arctic|ice melting in the Arctic]], stating that "we may build new drilling platforms and retrieve natural resources hidden below the sea bed", as well as "chasing the pirates, terrorists and ecologists that will come to hang around". The bloggers subsequently responded: "Our recent entry on north-west passage was widely discussed but unfortunately misunderstood. The readers considered the forthcoming, bitter, but unfortunately possible scenario as [an] option we like. We do not. But how to react to the featured situation? Should we be silent? We are glad, that the topic caused so much interest and discussion, because the matter is really very serious."<ref>Vaughan, Adam: [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/oct/10/malting-arctic-ice-pirate-chases-cop19-organisers "Arctic melt means more pirate chases, say Polish climate hosts"] in ''[[The Guardian]]'', 10 October 2013</ref>
Organizers from the Ministry of the Economy in Poland were also strongly criticised for co-hosting an event with the [[World Coal Association]] alongside the UNFCCC talks. This has been seen as a provocation against changing the energy source mix in Poland.<ref>{{cite news|last=Scislowska|first=Monika|title=Poland To Host Both UN Climate Change Conference And International Coal Summit|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/08/poland-un-climate-chage-coal-summit_n_4237742.html|accessdate=12 November 2013|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=8 November 2013}}</ref>
The dismissal of the conference president Marcin Korolec from his cabinet position as minister of environmental during the negotiations has been seen by delegates as a further sign of Poland's lack of commitment to progress global action on global warming. Prime minister [[Donald Tusk]] stated that the dismissal had to do with the need for "radical acceleration of shale gas operations".<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/nov/20/climate-talks-polish-environment-minister-sacked?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 "Climate talks: Polish environment minister sacked to accelerate shale gas operations"], in ''[[The Guardian]]'', 20 November 2013</ref>
===Industrialised countries=== The [[International Energy Agency]] has continually urged industrialised countries to reduce [[fossil fuel subsidies]]. It is expected that these subsidy actions will not be addressed.<ref>{{cite book|title=World Energy Outlook|year=2013|publisher=International Energy Agency|location=Paris|isbn=978-92-64-18084-0|page=57}}</ref>
Several countries attending the COP 19 have been criticised for poor performance on stated environmental pollution targets. While the United States reduced its emissions of {{CO2}} in 2012 by 11.8 percent compared to 2005, the largest reduction of any country, others have not done so well.<Ref> White House Fact Sheet June 25, 2013 http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/06/25/fact-sheet-president-obama-s-climate-action-plan. </ref>

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox artist <!-- | name = Dailey, Brian --> | image = Brian Dailey self portrait.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1951|8|12|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Pittsburg, California]] | nationality = American | training = [[Otis Art Institute]] MFA, 1975 [[University of Southern California]] PhD 1987 | field = artist, [[international security]] | movement = [[conceptualism]], performance, [[eclecticism]] |website = http://briandaileyart.com/ }} '''Brian Dailey''' (born August 12, 1951) is an American artist noted for his careers in both art and international relations. His work in a variety of mediums—including photography, film, installations, and painting—engages with the social, political, and cultural issues of our times and is not easily categorized. Dailey's art reflects his unconventional evolution as an artist and multifaceted life experiences, which include national level involvement in arms control, space policy, intelligence systems, and international security.<ref>[https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4225/oral-histories/dailey.pdf Johnson Space Center Oral History Project: Brian Dailey]</ref> He is based in the Washington DC metropolitan area and maintains studios in the District and Woodstock, Virginia.<ref>[http://briandaileyart.com/ Brian Dailey Art]</ref>
==Personal life==
Dailey was born in Pittsburg, California. His parents divorced when he was three, precipitating his mother's return to her native New Zealand with Dailey and his sister and the family's subsequent relocation to England. They returned to the United States in 1956 and resided in Santa Monica, California, where he spent his youth.<ref>Joan Anderson, "And the Shenandoah County Award for Best Extra Goes to....," ''Mountain Courier'' (February 2015).</ref> He took up photography at the age of 12, beginning his formal photographic training after entering [[Pacific Palisades High School]].
Dailey attended Ventura College where he developed an interest in ceramic sculpture, shifting the direction of his art career.<ref>"College Art Guild Winner," ''The Ventura County Star-Free Press'' (December 29, 1971):B-7</ref> On the basis of his portfolio, he was accepted directly into the Masters program at [[Otis Art Institute]] in Los Angeles where he became interested in performance, conceptual art, and video technology.<ref>[http://briandaileyart.com/ Brian Dailey Art]</ref> In 1984 he married fellow artist Paula Ballo, who succumbed to cancer in 2016.
==Art Career in Los Angeles==
As a student at Otis Art Institute (MFA, 1975) and in his ensuing art career in Los Angeles, Dailey participated in the creative experimentation defining the artistic milieu in California in this era.<ref>[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/artsdesk/visual-arts/2013/11/13/brian-dailey-on-the-palette-of-american-politics/ Louis Jacobson, "Brian Dailey on the Palette of American Politics"]</ref> In his installation works from this period, he explored the role of the artist in the causal process. His performance pieces placed an emphasis on active viewer engagement.<ref>*"Vice," ''High Performance'' 1, no. 1 (February 1978): 28–29</ref>
Upon graduation from Otis, Dailey began his art career exhibiting his performance and conceptual works in various institutions in Los Angeles and was represented by the Roger Wong Gallery.<ref>Artists Files. Los Angeles Museum of Art / Roger Wong Gallery records. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.[http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/los-angeles-museum-art--roger-wong-gallery-records-6530]</ref> His work from this period includes painting, sculpture, and performance art, reflecting the pluralistic forms of creative expression and the political and social engagement generated by the Los Angeles artistic community.
Travel and exposure to diverse cultures had a significant impact on Dailey. During his art education, he traveled to Europe, visiting museums to study paintings and sculptures that inspired him as a student and visiting countries in the [[Eastern Bloc]] to learn about the communist political system. In 1976, Dailey set out to Japan with the aim of working with the director [[Akira Kurosawa]], whose films were a source of inspiration. He traveled on the [[Trans Siberian Express]] to Japan, transiting through the Soviet Union.<ref>''Johnson Space Center Oral History Project: Brian Dailey,'' NASA, p. 8 [https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4225/oral-histories/dailey.pdf]</ref> Meeting artists and writers in East Berlin and along the train stops in Siberia, he became increasingly interested in international relations and the issue of artistic freedom in totalitarian regimes.
Dailey's residence in Japan was brief. Discovering that Kurosawa's professional and private life was at a nadir and confronting the challenges of working in Japan, he returned to Los Angeles where he worked with [[Sam Francis]] in his Litho Shop and with a number of other leading artists in his capacity as an assistant at [[ACE Gallery]] in Venice, California. He also worked for the architect James De Long, a student of [[Frank Lloyd Wright]].<ref>[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/latimes/obituary.aspx?n=james-e-de-long&pid=164580042 James De Long, Obituary, LA Times, May 2, 2013]</ref> His growing interest in film and video led to his working as a grip at the [[American Film Institute]] in Los Angeles, where he learned filmmaking. Having worked on AFI projects he began to work on his own films using a 16mm Beaulieu camera.
==Arms Control and International Security==
In 1981, Dailey's interest in international affairs and the [[Cold War]] led him to pursue a doctorate and a career in international relations. He studied arms control, Russian studies, and diplomatic history at the University of Southern California, receiving his degree in 1987 with a dissertation on the [[Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty]].<ref>Brian D. Dailey, "Deception and Self-Deception in Arms Control: The ABM and Outer Space Treaties Reconsidered." Ph.D. Dissertation, University of Southern California, August 1987.</ref>
Dailey’s career in international affairs began in 1984 with an internship as assistant director for chemical warfare negotiations in [[the Pentagon]]. In January 1985, he became an Adjunct Professor of National Security Affairs at the [[Naval Postgraduate School]], Monterey, California.<ref>Lockheed Martin Names Brian Dailey to New Consolidated Washington, D.C., Post [http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/lockheed-martin-names-brian-dailey-to-new-consolidated-washington-dc-post-73607692.html]</ref> In this capacity, he managed a three-year Soviet deception project for the Pentagon's Director of Net Assessment and the U.S. Army as well as teaching courses on modern revolution and terrorism, nuclear targeting, strategic deception, and intelligence systems and products. In 1987, he co-edited and published the anthology ''Soviet Strategic Deception.''<ref>Brian D. Dailey and Patrick J. Parker, ed., ''Soviet Strategic Deception,'' Lexington Books, 1987.</ref>
In January 1988, Dailey became a professional staff member of the [[Senate Armed Service Committee]], assigned to the Subcommittee on Strategic Forces and Nuclear Deterrence.<ref>Conventional Forces in Europe (CFE) Treaty Hearings Before the Committee on Armed Services [http://fas.org/nuke/control/cfe/congress/22j1.htm]</ref> He was responsible for matters on arms control, missile defense, special access programs, as well as space and intelligence systems.<ref>David C. Morrison, "Sam Nunn Inc.," ''National Journal'' (June 15, 1991): 1485</ref> In that capacity, he was also the minority staff liaison to [[Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]]. In 1992, he was appointed Executive Secretary of the [[National Space Council]] in the [[White House]], where he was responsible for coordinating U.S. space policy for civil, commercial, defense, and intelligence issues.<ref>[https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4225/oral-histories/dailey.pdf Johnson Space Center Oral History Project: Brian Dailey]</ref>
At the end of the Cold War, Dailey transitioned to the private sector. He left the White House in 1993 to work for the [[Lockheed Corporation]], where he was responsible for commercial programs including their joint ventures in the former Soviet Union.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=1245769&ticker=LMT&previousCapId=370857&previousTitle=BOEING%2520CO%252FTHE Executive Profile: Brian D. Dailey]</ref> He went on to become a Senior Vice President and Corporate Officer of [[Lockheed Martin]].<ref>Lockheed Martin Names Brian Dailey to New Consolidated Washington, D.C., Post [http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/lockheed-martin-names-brian-dailey-to-new-consolidated-washington-dc-post-73607692.html]</ref> In the course of his work in art, government, and the private sector, he traveled to more than 80 countries on all continents more than 50 times to the Soviet Union and Russia.
==Return to Art==
Dailey returned to art full-time in 2008, leveraging his experiences in the intervening decades in his creative practice.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/10/26/AR2008102601832.html Lockheed's Top Lobbyist Calling It a Career]</ref> His approach to art is both conceptual and performance based, inviting the viewer's participation. In his frequent use of the photographic ''[[tableau vivant]],'' Dailey explores topical existential questions and utilizes composite imagery as a vehicle for making critical commentary on contemporary social and political issues.<ref>[http://briandaileyart.com/ Brian Dailey Art]</ref> These staged "living pictures" have been featured in exhibitions in Europe and the United States (see selected exhibitions below).
Dailey's early interest in film resurfaces in his current practice. His video ''Jikai'' (2012) alludes to Shakespeare's ''[[The Merchant of Venice]],'' employing a moth fatally drawn to light. Dedicated to Kurosawa, the video is a meditation on political disintegration. ''Jikai'' was screened on multiple synchronized monitors in New York City in February 2014 as the featured video in the Times Square Midnight Moment series.<ref>February Midnight Moment to Showcase Brian Dailey's ''Moth to a Flame'' Video Showcasing the Power and Danger of Attraction (January 31, 2014): [http://www.timessquarenyc.org/times-square-arts/media/press-releases/brian-dailey-jikai/index.aspx] [http://www.timessquarenyc.org/times-square-arts/projects/midnight-moment/jikai/index.aspx]</ref>
Dailey has had solo exhibitions in Los Angeles, New York, and Bulgaria and participated in a number of group shows in the United States, Europe, and Russia. His mid-career retrospective, ''Declassified: Unraveling a Paradox'', took place at Bulgaria's [[National Art Gallery (Bulgaria)|National Art Gallery]] in Sofia in 2014.<ref>Lilyana Karadzhova, "Declassified: American Artist Brian Dailey Unravels Paradoxes in Sofia"[http://www.europost.bg/article?id=11789]</ref> Dailey was a featured speaker at FotoDC 2015, presenting his ''American in Color'' project as part of a series of talks on photobooks.<ref>[http://www.fotodc.org/events/2015/9/23/fototalks-brian-dailey FotoTalks, FotoDC 2015]</ref>
Dailey's encrypted ''Riddle'' series was featured in the exhibition ''GEOMETRIX: Line, Form, Subversion'', organized by Curator's Office at three-venues in Washington, DC from January 14 to April 16, 2016.<ref>[http://www.curatorsoffice.com/20152016-geometrix/ Curator's Office GEOMETRIX: LINE, FORM, SUBVERSION]</ref> ''Lamentations'',<ref>[https://brian-dailey-6t9u.squarespace.com/lamentations/ Brian Dailey Art, "Lamentations"]</ref> a meditation in two and three dimensions on nuclear theology and its implications in our atomic age, was featured in an interview with the artist in the Johns Hopkin's Journal of the Association for the Study of Arts of the Present.<ref>"To Look Is To Think: A Conversation with Brian Dailey," ''ASAP/Journal,'' Volume 2, Number 1 (January 2017): pp. 49-70. [https://muse.jhu.edu/article/649708]</ref> Three works from the ''Lamentations'' series were included in Absence and Presence: Arts in Foggy Bottom Outdoor Sculpture Biennial 2018, Washington DC <ref>[http://artsinfoggybottom.com/#!/current]</ref> and the associated exhibition at the Watergate Gallery. Dailey's ''Words'' series,<ref>[http://www.briandaileyart.com/words/ Brian Dailey Art, ''Words'']</ref> an international exploration of the role of language in the construction of cultural identity in the global age, premiered in January 2018 at the Katzen Art Center at American University in Washington D.C.<ref>[https://www.villagevoice.com/2018/02/23/brian-daileys-strange-odyssey-from-art-to-terror-and-back-again/]</ref>
Dailey is represented by the Baahng Gallery, 790 Madison Ave., New York, NY

revision.text:
'''Corruption in [[Navarre]]''' refers to a quick succession of corruption scandals which have come to light since 2012 referring to the [[Navarrese People's Union|UPN]]'s tenure in office (since 1996). However, amidst heated political confrontation since the late days of Franco's dictatorship, the first corruption cases erupted early on, going back to the first government cabinets formed after the establishment of Navarre's "Betterment" (the ''Amejoramiento'', a Navarre-specific administrative system, 1982).
In 1996, [[Miguel Sanz]]'s government started a 15-year period of distancing and breaking of virtually all historic institutional bonds and cultural cooperation with [[Southern Basque Country|fellow Basque provinces]], citing fears of a "Basque nationalist takeover", and billing themselves as the guarantee of Navarrese institutions and identity. However, two prime rallying points and historic flagship institutions of all the Navarrese, i.e.[[Caja Navarra]] and [[Osasuna]], collapsed during the UPN's tenure in office.
==Recent scandals and irregularities== [[File:Rajoy con Yolanda Barcina.jpg|thumb|Yolanda Barcina, former president of Navarre (2011-2015), shaking hands with Spanish premier Mariano Rajoy]] *[[Caja Navarra scandal]]: Erupted in 2012 under the presidency of [[Enrique Goñi]], resulting in the disappearance of the historic Navarrese savings bank. *[[Cervera affair]]: A development of the Caja Navarra scandal, it jumped onto the spotlight in December 2012 when [[Santiago Cervera]], a Navarrese [[Popular Party (Spain)|Spanish Conservative]] leader, was found collecting an envelope containing 25,000 euros at the old rampart of Pamplona, and arrested on the spot. The money happened to be a bait planted by the Civil Guard, but Cervera was accused of attempting to blackmail former [[Caja Navarra]] CEO Jose Antonio Asiain in exchange for keeping silent on inconvenient Caja Navarra facts.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lanas|first=Pedro|date=2014-01-20|title=El misterio del chantaje trampa al diputado Cervera |url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2014/01/20/actualidad/1390244904_522273.html |newspaper=El País|location=Pamplona |access-date=2015-06-02}}</ref> Right the opposite, besides claiming that he was duped, Cervera blamed the whole affair on his opposition to "the looting" taking place in Caja Navarra, aligning in that denouncement with the Navarrese Basque nationalists.<ref>{{cite news |last=Carrillo|first=Xabier|date= |title=Santiago Cervera sigue defendiendo su inocencia|url=http://www.eitb.eus/es/noticias/politica/videos/detalle/3252884/video-santiago-cervera--juicio-exdiputado-pp/ |newspaper=EITB|access-date=2015-06-02}}</ref> *Racing circuit of [[Los Arcos]]: A [[white elephant]] case operating at a loss with questioned allocation of works and UPN's government intervention. Designed under [[Miguel Sanz]] and Yolanda Barcina, the project was allocated to the building company ''Samaniego'' but it soon risked bankruptcy, in the face of which the regional government purchased 95% of its capital. The Government of Navarre had to request a credit to meet expenses incurred on the construction works, a figure rising to 62 million euros. Once the circuit opened in 2010, it operated at a loss from scratch (2,6 million euros on its first year). In December 2013, the regional government sold all of the facilities to ''Los Arcos Motorsport'', leading to a balance sheet of 45 millions in losses.<ref>{{cite news |last=Orzaiz|first=Jon|date=2015-04-03|title=Absurdoari monumentuak |url=http://www.berria.eus/albisteak/109660/absurdoari_monumentuak.htm |newspaper=Berria|location=Pamplona|access-date=2015-05-20}}</ref> *Public Health Service catering case: Recurrent complaints by patients over the catering service (contractor Mediterranea de Catering) due to poor standards in food, denied by the Government of Navarre. A tribunal imposed a fine on the catering service. The recently outsourced service was found to be operating at higher expenses than the regular public catering service in force up to that point, as disclosed by the Accountancy Chamber of Navarre (the Comptos).<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=2015-02-09|title=La jueza confirma la multa por la comida de los hospitales navarros: 6.000 euros por sus errores "constantes" |url=http://www.eldiario.es/norte/navarra/ultima_hora/confirma-servicio-privatizado-hospitales-constantes_0_354865172.html |newspaper=El Diario|location= |access-date=2015-05-21}}</ref> Opposition parties, besides condemning the lack of transparency, labeled "a scandal" the conclusions of the Accountancy Chamber's report, one that pointed to financial losses coupled with a deterioration in food standards following outsourcing of the service. These parties demanded in turn the resignation of regional Health Secretary Marta Vera. Just the opposite, UPN's regional government, while "respecting" the conclusions, protested their not considering "the actual circumstances" of the moment the privatization decision was made.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=2014-06-24|title=La oposición ve "escandaloso" el informe sobre la privatización de las cocinas de hospitales |url=http://www.eldiario.es/norte/navarra/ultima_hora/Solo-privatizacion-servicio-hospital-empresa_0_274373445.html |newspaper=El Diario|location= |access-date=2015-08-18}}</ref> *Health Service crisis: In September 2014, Juan José Rubio, Chief Manager of the Navarre Health Service (''Osasunbidea''), stepped down on operative and managerial outlook discrepancies with Health Secretary of Navarre Marta Vera (UPN); Rubio had been asked to "remain shut in his office" and "out of touch with the board of directors."<ref>{{cite news |last=EP|first=|date=2014-09-17|title=Vera me pidió que no saliera del despacho y que trabajara desde la distancia y sin comunicación con el equipo directivo |url=http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/2014/09/17/sociedad/navarra/vera-me-pidio-que-no-saliera-del-despacho-y-que-trabajara-desde-la-distancia-y-sin-comunicacion-con-el-equipo-directivo |newspaper=Noticas de Navarra|location=Pamplona |access-date=2015-06-07}}</ref> Mr. Rubio, who had been appointed to the highest position in Osasunbidea by the regional government, dwelt later on details, claiming the "organization is sick", involving serious dysfunctions and discontentment among professional and patients alike and pointing to privileges in the Health Service favouring "certain families and crusts" from Navarre. He called for the institution's urgent and necessary re-foundation.<ref>{{cite news |last=EFE EPE|first=|date=2014-09-30|title=EL EXGERENTE EN COMISIÓN PARLAMENTARIA Juanjo Rubio, exgerente: 'La organización del SNS-O está enferma' |url=http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/2014/09/30/sociedad/navarra/juanjo-rubio-exgerente-la-organizacion-del-sns-o-esta-enferma|location=Pamplona |access-date=2015-06-07}}</ref> The regional party UPN, in office, put Mr. Rubio's resignation down to his "inability to accommodate." Opposition parties made Ms. Vera fully responsible for the current state of the public Health Service.<ref>{{cite news |last=Montañes|first=Garikoitz|date=2014-09-30|title=Un sistema de salud público en el que importa tu apellido o condición social |url=http://www.eldiario.es/norte/navarra/ultima_hora/exgerente-servicio-Salud-necesita-refundarse_0_308669278.html%202014-09-30|location=Pamplona |access-date=2015-06-07}}</ref> *City Police scandals: A series of abuses and arbitrary behaviour detected on the chief officials of the corps Simon Santamaria and Ignacio Polo. The Professional Union of City Police Officers of Spain pointed out that the "work atmosphere between officials and superiors is very tense", with the Pamplona City Police showing the highest work absenteeism rate in like environments across Spain, due to stress and depression. The union's serious allegations against the chief head Santamaria included bullying, harassment, false evidence, and reprisals against police officers, besides denouncing mayor [[Enrique Maya]]'s championing of the chief official.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=2013-08-16|title=Prevaricación, coacción, vejaciones. Un sindicato de la Policía Municipal de Pamplona presenta una denuncia contra su jefe y varios mandos que salpica al alcalde de la ciudad, Enrique Maya |url=http://www.elconfidencialautonomico.com/navarra/Prevaricacion-Policia-Municipal-Pamplona-Enrique_0_2108789110.html |newspaper=El Confidencial Autonómico|location= |access-date=2015-05-21}}</ref> The [[Navarrese People's Union|UPN]]-appointed Santamaria eventually resigned after political opposition build-up, with opposition parties considering the situation "untenable" and the corps "a paramilitary body".<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=2013-08-16|title=La oposición de Pamplona censura la gestión de Simón Santamaría y espera una Policía Municipal "de cercanía" |url=http://www.europapress.es/navarra/noticia-oposicion-pamplona-censura-gestion-simon-santamaria-espera-policia-municipal-cercania-20150116110411 |newspaper=Europa Press|location= |access-date=2015-05-21}}</ref> In stark contrast, Maya saluted Santamaria's job during his tenure as "very good".<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=2015-01-16|title=Maya: 'Santamaría se va por razones personales; la ciudad no es nada fácil'|url=http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/2015/01/16/vecinos/pamplona/maya-santamaria-se-va-por-razones-personales-esta-ciudad-no-es-nada-facil |newspaper=Noticias de Navarra|location= |access-date=2015-05-21}}</ref> In similar circumstances, Pamplona's Citizen Security deputy of Pamplona Ignacio Polo (UPN) was convicted of drink-driving, with his allegations against lower-rank police officers conducting the alcohol check being dismissed.<ref>{{cite news |last=Montañes|first=Garikoitz|date=2015-02-16|title=El exedil de Seguridad Ciudadana de Pamplona Ignacio Polo, culpable por conducir ebrio |url=http://www.eldiario.es/norte/navarra/ultima_hora/Seguridad-Ciudadana-Pamplona-Ignacio-Polo_0_357314398.html |newspaper=El Diario|location= |access-date=2015-05-21}}</ref> *[[Osasuna]] scandal: This erupted in early 2015 related to the iconic Navarrese top-flight football club, with links to the Treasury of the Government of Navarre, involving tax evasion, turning a blind eye in governmental surveillance duties, match fixing practices, etc. A UPN-PP-PSN majority vote in the Parliament of Navarre passed a blind fiscal bailout on Osasuna without waiting to audit results while refusing to hand over Osasuna's accountancy information to opposition parties for their consideration ahead of the vote on the law. PSN's spokesperson claimed "they had not been told" of any irregular finances by the directive board of Osasuna, while on the opposite side, [[EH Bildu]] branded the whole affair "a disgrace".<ref>{{cite news |last=Carrillo|first=Xabier|date= |title=Osasuna: UPN y PSN, 'preocupados'; Bildu lo tacha de 'escandaloso'|url=http://www.eitb.eus/es/noticias/politica/videos/detalle/2982984/video-osasuna-presunto-amano-partidos--24-millones-justificar/ |newspaper=EITB|access-date=2015-05-20}}</ref> The football club owed the Government of Navarre 52,8 million euros, but after handing over its patrimony to the government of Navarre, the club's debt rises to 20,6 million euros after the law passed by UPN, [[People's Party (Spain)|PP]] and [[Socialist Party of Navarre|PSN]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Lanas|first=Pedro|date=2015-04-30|title=20,6 millones, la deuda fiscal |url=http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/2015/04/30/osasuna/206-millones-la-deuda-fiscal |newspaper=Noticias de Navarra|location= |access-date=2015-05-20}}</ref> The club is under scrutiny by the European Commission in May 2015.<ref>{{cite news |last=EFE|first=|date=2015-05-20|title=Bruselas mantiene abierta una investigación a Osasuna por ayudas de Estado |url=http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/2015/05/20/osasuna/bruselas-mantiene-abierta-una-investigacion-a-osasuna-por-ayudas-de-estado|newspaper=Noticias de Navarra|location=Pamplona|access-date=2015-05-20}}</ref>
==Governmental corruption record== [[File:Gabriel Urralburu (cropped).jpg|thumb|Gabriel Urralburu, former president of Navarre]] *FASA affair (1980-1983): A scandal of public funds embezzlement involving [[Unión de Centro Democrático|UCD]] high-ranking official and president of [[Navarre]] [[Jaime del Burgo|Jaime Ignacio del Burgo]] (1979-1983), eventually impeached by the parliament and deposed by the Regional Government (1983). Years later, a tribunal declared him innocent.<ref>{{cite news |last=López Muñoz |first=Ismael |date=1986-04-17|title=La justicia y el 'caso FASA-Del Burgo' |url=http://elpais.com/diario/1986/04/27/opinion/514936809_850215.html |newspaper=El País|location=Madrid|access-date=2015-05-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/27466 |title=Jaime Ignacio del Burgo|last1=Sainz Pascual|first1=Zuriñe|last2= |first2= |date=2012 |website=Auñamendi Entziklopedia|publisher=EuskoMedia Fundazioa|access-date=2015-05-15|quote=}}</ref> *Urralburu affair: [[Socialist Party of Navarre|Socialist]] president of Navarre (1983-1991) involved in corruption for kickbacks received in public works. Condemned to prison term in 1995.<ref>{{cite news |last=|first= |date=2012-03-20|title=El cuarto presidente condenado de la democracia|url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2012/03/20/actualidad/1332237129_147650.html |newspaper=El País|location=Madrid|access-date=2015-05-20}}</ref> In 1998, he was also convicted of continued bribery and offences against governmental treasury and mismanagement of public funds within the [[Luis Roldán]] case, centred also in Navarre, for which he was given a 11-year-prison sentence.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/27466 |title=Gabriel Urralburu|last1=Arozamena Ayala|first1=Ainhoa|last2= |first2= |date= |website=Auñamendi Entziklopedia|publisher=EuskoMedia Fundazioa|access-date=2015-05-15|quote=}}</ref> However, by 2001 he was on parole months after getting imprisoned.<ref>{{cite news |last=Checa |first=Arturo|date=2013-01-25|title=La buena vida de nuestros corruptos |url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20130127/mas-actualidad/sociedad/buena-vida-nuestros-corruptos-201301251911.html|newspaper=El Correo|location=Bizkaia|access-date=2015-05-20}}</ref> *Otano affair: [[Socialist Party of Navarre|Socialist]] president of Navarre Javier Otano (1995-1996) was leading a tripartite coalition with parties [[Eusko Alkartasuna]] and CDN when revelations broke out of the existence of a bank account under his name in Switzerland, with Otano announcing his resignation from office almost immediately.<ref>{{cite news |last=Muez|first=Mikel|date=1996-06-19|title=Dimisión fulminante del socialista Javier Otano al descubrirle la juez una cuenta en Suiza|url=http://elpais.com/diario/1996/06/19/espana/835135226_850215.html |newspaper=El País|location=Madrid|access-date=2015-05-20}}</ref> Otano categorically denied any personal intent for his signature on the account, signing only "on request of Urralburu" in 1991 for the sake of the party. It was revealed as a case of illegal funding of the Spanish Socialists in Navarre and fraud to the Navarre Treasury driven by Gabriel Urralburu,<ref>{{cite news |last=Lopez|first=B.|date=2005-06-22|title=La comisión del "caso Otano" concluye que el PSN se benefició del dinero de Suiza|url=http://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-22-06-2005/abc/Nacional/la-comision-del-caso-otano-concluye-que-el-psn-se-beneficio-del-dinero-de-suiza_203313352889.html|newspaper=ABC|location=Madrid|access-date=2015-05-20}}</ref> with deep political implications. The coalition broke up right away, and [[Juan Cruz Alli]], the leading figure of [[Democrats' Convergence of Navarre|CDN]] (a splinter party of UPN), blamed the scandal directly on "[[Socialist Party of Navarre|Socialist]] disloyalty" for demolishing "the possibility of building an alternative Government of Navarre [other than UPN or PSN] integrating diverse political options and therefore betting on the support of the bulk of the Navarre society."<ref>{{cite news |last=|first=|date=2008-03-29|title=Alli deja la dirección de CDN culpando de su deriva a la "deslealtad" del PSN en 1996|url=http://gara.naiz.eus/paperezkoa/20080329/69891/es/Alli-deja-direccion-CDN-culpando-su-deriva-deslealtad-PSN-1996|newspaper=Gara|location=|access-date=2015-05-20}}</ref> *[[Navarre#Present-day political dynamics|Lourdes Goicoechea scandal]] (2014): A scandal erupting in [[Yolanda Barcina]]'s cabinet involving embezzlement and preferential treatment including the [[Opus Dei]]. The Parliament of Navarre launched a parliamentary probe, concluding that the president of Navarre did not explain irregularities or account for obscure practices, for which a majority resolution censured UPN's Barcina. Still, despite pointing that UPN's regional government is "tainted by a corruption scandal" and declaring that "ETA and Bildu are scarecrows used by the same old people to remain in power no matter what",<ref>{{cite video |people= |date=2014-02-14 |title=Jiménez: "O Barcina dimite y convoca elecciones o la echamos con una moción"|url=http://www.lasexta.com/programas/al-rojo-vivo/entrevistas/jimenez-barcina-dimite-convoca-elecciones-echamos-mocion_2014021400173.html |format= |medium= |language= |publisher=La Sexta |location= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=2015-05-21|time=02’50, 05'37|id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }}</ref> [[Socialist Party of Navarre|Spanish Socialists in Navarre]] failed to remove ("kick out") Barcina from office, leaving a deadlocked government, as instructed by the Socialist party executive in Madrid.<ref>{{cite news |last=|first=|date=2014-03-07|title=El PSN acata pero critica el veto del PSOE a la moción de censura en Navarra|url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2014/03/06/actualidad/1394117803_489963.html|newspaper=El País|location=Madrid|access-date=2015-05-21}}</ref> Weeks after erupting the political scandal, the Spanish Supreme Court of Justice stated that no evidence of corruption or mismanagement had been found in the Goicoechea affair and closed the file.<ref>{{cite news |last=|first=|date=2014-06-17|title=Goicoechea se muestra contenta del archivo de las denuncias|url=http://www.europapress.es/nacional/noticia-goicoechea-muestra-contenta-archivo-denuncias-kontuz-ela-demuestra-no-caso-20140617185405.html|newspaper=Europa Press|location=Madrid|access-date=2015-07-17}}</ref>

[[File:Courage to Resist Logo.jpg|thumb|The logo for the organization Courage to Resist]]
'''Courage to Resist''' (CTR) formed as an organization in the [[San Francisco]], CA area during the early part of the [[Iraq War]] (often called the 2nd Iraq war), which began in 2003. It now has members spread around the U.S., but is still mainly concentrated in the San Francisco Bay Area. The group’s overall mission is to support U.S military war resisters, including helping them with legal fees. They have defended and supported well-known resisters like [[Chelsea Manning]] and [[Reality Winner]], and in 2018 began encouraging soldiers to refuse to be involved with the immigrant detention camps and other immigrant operations of the U.S. military. Their principle slogans are “Supporting the troops who refuse to fight!” and "Towards a World Without War!" They support those “who face consequences for acting on conscience, in opposition to illegal wars, occupations, [and] the policies of empire”.
== Founding == The Iraq War started amid controversy with many questioning everything from its legality to the existence in Iraq of “weapons of mass destruction”. According to French academic [[Dominique Reynié]], between 3 January and 12 April 2003, {{Nowrap|36 million}} people across the globe took part in almost 3,000 protests against war in Iraq, with [[15 February 2003 anti-war protests|demonstrations on 15 February 2003]] being the largest.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Reynié |first1=Dominique |date=2005 |title=Globalized protest: Demonstrating in the age of globalization: the case of rallies against the Iraq war in 2003 |url=https://www.academia.edu/6081355/GLOBALIZED_PROTEST._DEMONSTRATING_IN_THE_AGE_OF_GLOBALIZATION_THE_CASE_OF_RALLIES_AGAINST_THE_IRAQ_WAR_IN_2003_1 |journal=www.academia.edu |access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref>. This questioning was also occurring in the U.S. military and on April 1, 2003 Stephen E. Funk, a U.S. Marine Corps Lance Corporal Reservist, became the first of numerous soldier resisters when he held a press conference outside the [[Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton|Camp Pendleton Marine Base]] in Oceanside, CA publicly announcing his refusal to participate in the war<ref>{{cite news |date=2003-04-01 |first=Laurie |last=Goodstein |title=A Nation at War: Dissent; Conscientious Objector Numbers Are Small but Growing|work=The New York Times}}</ref>. Like minded civilians and veterans of earlier wars stepped forward to support Funk and then decided, as other soldiers refused orders and faced courts martial, that a broader organization was needed. It wouldn’t be enough, they thought, to form a committee in support of each individual objector – the result was Courage to Resist.<ref>{{cite AV media |people=Jeff Paterson |date=2012-02-04 |title=Jeff Paterson and the Founding of Courage to Resist |medium=Video |language=English |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jxMUFTzNiXA |access-date=2018-11-19 |location=YouTube}}</ref>
== Jeff Paterson ==
[[File:Jeff Paterson Refusing to Board Aircraft to Persian Gulf 1990.jpg|thumb|left|Marine Corporal Jeff Paterson refused to board military aircraft in Hawaii enroute to Persian Gulf on August 7, 1990.]]
One of Funk’s early supporters was Jeff Paterson, a former Marine who, because he was the first soldier to publically refuse orders to the 1st Iraq War in 1990, felt a particular kinship with Funk. Paterson had been a Marine for five years and was on the verge of returning to civilian life when his discharge was cancelled in lieu of orders to the Persian Gulf. On August 7, 1990, as his unit boarded an aircraft in Hawaii, he sat down on the tarmac and refused to move. A week later he, like Funk, held a press conference where he stated, “I will not be a pawn in America’s power plays for profit and oil in the Middle East”.<ref>{{cite news |date=1990-09-13 |first=Robert |last=Stewart |title=Anti-War Sentiment is Seen Growing in the Armed Forces|work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=1990-09-23 |first=Colman |last=McCarthy |title=This Time, the Pacifists Are Starting Sooner |work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=2001-01-21 |title=Gulf War Resister Jeff Paterson: Up Against the War Machine |work=Revolutionary Worker |url=https://revcom.us/a/v22/1080-89/1087/jeff_paterson.htm}}</ref> Paterson was a founding member of and has served for many years as the Project Director for CTR<ref>{{cite news |date=2011-11-02 |first=Ashley |last=Fantz |title=Key People In WikiLeaks Saga Are Divided On Assange Extradition|work=St. Joseph News-Press}}</ref>.
== Opposition to the Iraq War == CTR supported several early public resisters to the Iraq War, including Army Staff Sergeants Camilo Mejia and Kevin Benderman, Navy Petty Officer Pablo Paredes, Army medic Agustin Aguayo, Private First Class [[Robin Long]], and Army First Lieutenant Ehren Watada, and continued to support military resisters throughout the war<ref>{{cite news |date=2008-08-23 |first=Dan |last=Frosch |title=Soldier Who Deserted to Canada Draws 15-Month Term |work=New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=2005-05-28 |first=Joe |last=Garofoli |title=Anti-war sailor lifts foes of Iraq policy |work=San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=2006-09-27 |first=Adrienne |last=Ziegler |title=I'm Not A Deserter or a Coward: Soldier Surrenders at Fort Irwin |work=McClatchy - Tribune Business News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://peaceandjustice.org.uk/newsletter/p-j-news-february-16/unsung-heroes-courage-to-resist/ |title=Unsung Heroes: Courage to Resist |last=Ames |first=Izi |date=2016-02-02 |publisher=Edinburgh Peace and Justice Centre |access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=2006-06-27 |first=Alex |last=Fryer |title=Opponents of Iraq War Rally Around Lt. Watada |work=Seattle News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=2006-12-10 |first=Cecilia M. |last=Vega |title=Troops Opposed to Iraq War Get Show of Support |work=San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref>. They raised money to build public support and to help with legal defense. They staged rallies outside the military bases where resisters were being court martialed, demonstrated outside military recruiting stations, and participated in national days of actions to oppose the war and support war resisters.<ref>{{cite news |date=2007-01-31 |title=Do you support the troops who oppose war in Iraq? |work=Redlands Daily Facts}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=2005-03-20 |first=Robert D. |last=McFadden |title=Two Years After Iraq Invasion, Protesters Hold Small Rallies |work=New York Times}}</ref>
==Opposition to the War in Afghanistan ==
CTR supported the earliest public resisters to the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)]] including [[Victor Agosto]]<ref>{{cite news |date=2009-08-05 |first=James C. |last=McKinley Jr. |title=Soldier Who Didn’t Obey Is Jailed |work=New York Times}}[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/06/us/06soldier.html]</ref> and Travis Bishop.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wri-irg.org/en/node/8561/ |title=Conscientious objector Travis Bishop sentenced to one year in prison |date=2009-08-14 |publisher=War Resisters' International |access-date=2018-11-21}}</ref>
== Israeli War Resisters Support == CTR members traveled to Israel and Palestine, learning much about Israeli war resistance movements. They talked with former Israeli soldiers about their experiences “carrying out acts of brutality and occupation” and decided as an organization to support their resistance to the Israeli military. In 2008 they were instrumental in issuing a statement signed by 26 U.S. military soldiers and veterans who refused to fight in Iraq and Afghanistan, which supported Israeli [[Refusal to serve in the IDF|Shministim]] (Hebrew for “12th graders”) who were also resisting military service.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.commondreams.org/views/2008/12/18/taking-stand-our-fellow-war-resisters |title=Taking a Stand With Our Fellow War-Resisters |date=2008-12-18 |publisher=Common Dreams |access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref> In 2018 they supported Tamar Ze’evi, a 15-year-old who spent 115 days in jail for refusing to enlist in the Israeli army.<ref>{{cite news |date=2017-03-24 |first=Gili |last=Cohen |title=After 115 Days in Jail, Conscientious Objector Tamar Zeevi Released From Israeli Army |work=Haaretz |url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-after-115-days-in-jail-conscientious-objector-released-from-israeli-army-1.5452760}}</ref>
== Chelsea Manning Support == [[File:Bradley-manning-pride001 (5877957820).jpg|thumb|Activists March for Bradley Manning at the 2011 San Francisco Pride Parade.]]In April 2010 a video showing a U.S. helicopter attack in [[Baghdad]] that killed eleven unarmed Iraqi civilians, including two [[Reuters]] employees, and seriously wounded two children was released by [[Wikileaks]] and quickly spread via the Internet and news media. On May 27, 2010, [[Chelsea Manning]], then known as Bradley Manning, was arrested and soon charged with espionage and “aiding the enemy”. Within days of Manning’s arrest, CTR joined with others to defend her and help raise money for her defense. On August 21, 2013 she was sentenced 35 years in prison, reduction in rank to private, forfeiture of all pay and allowances, and a dishonorable discharge. This was the longest sentence ever given to a whistleblower and was widely criticized.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/aug/21/bradley-manning-sentence-unjust Bradley Manning: a sentence both unjust and unfair], ''The Guardian'', August 21, 2013.</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/22/opinion/bradley-mannings-sentence-is-excessive.html Bradley Manning’s Excessive Sentence] ''[[The New York Times]]'', August 21, 2013.</ref> Throughout the trial and the 7 years Manning ended up serving in [[United States Disciplinary Barracks|Leavenworth prison]], CTR defended her and provided financial support through the Chelsea Manning Support Network. Manning's lead defense attorney, David Coombs, credited CTR directly for her early release: “If not for the efforts of Jeff Paterson and the Manning Support Network and Courage to Resist, there’s no way that a president would spend the political capital to grant a commutation”.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://couragetoresist.org/podcast-david-coombs-manning-attorney/ |title=PODCAST: DAVID COOMBS, CHELSEA MANNING’S TRIAL ATTORNEY |date=2017-05-14 |publisher=Courage To Resist |access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref> And Manning herself said on the [[NBC]] [[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]] show that she "would especially like to thank Courage to Resist and the Bradley Manning Support Network for their tireless efforts in raising awareness for my case and providing for my legal representation."[[File:Stop Recruiting Kids Image 1.jpg|thumb|left|Image used by the Stop Recruiting Kids Organization]]
== Counter-Recruiting == Throughout its existence, CTR has focused some of its efforts on U.S. military recruiting, including the efforts of the military to influence and recruit youth. They have organized demonstration and vigils outside military recruiting centers and have on at least one occasion forced a Marine recruiting center to close for several hours.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://couragetoresist.org/marinesshutdown/ |title=SUCCESSFUL SHUTDOWN OF MARINE RECRUITING CENTER! |date=2018-05-17 |publisher=Courage To Resist |access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=2008-01-21 |first=Mark |last=Brown |title=U.S. Military's Recruitment Tactics Faulted by Activists |work=The Register-Guard}}</ref> They use materials like the photo on the right from the ''Stop Recruiting Kids''[http://www.srkcampaign.org/] campaign.
== Reality Winner Support == [[Reality Winner]], a former U.S. Air Force intelligence specialist and military contractor, was arrested on June 3, 2017 and charged under the [[Espionage Act of 1917|Espionage Act]] with [[News leak|leaking]] a National Security Agency report about [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] to the news website ''[[The Intercept]]''.<ref>{{cite news |date=2018-06-26 |first=Charlie |last=Savage |first2=Alan |last2=Blinder |title=Reality Winner, N.S.A. Contractor Accused in Leak, Pleads Guilty |work=The New York Times}}</ref> Very quickly after her arrest, CTR began a campaign demanding the charges against her be dropped. They led the efforts to form the ''Stand With Reality'' support committee which stated that “the charge against Winner is grossly disproportionate to her alleged offense, and is designed to create a chilling effect on investigative journalism by dissuading sources from sharing information that is critical to the public interest.”<ref>{{cite web |url=https://couragetoresist.org/press-release-new-stand-reality-support-group-formed/ |title=SUPPORT GATHERS FOR NSA CONTRACTOR REALITY WINNER |date=2017-07-10 |publisher=Courage To Resist |access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://standwithreality.org |title=FRIENDS OF REALITY WINNER |date=2017-07-10 |access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref> On August 23, 2018 Winner received a sentence of 5 Years in prison.<ref>{{cite news |date=2018-08-23 |first=Dave |last=Philipps |title=Reality Winner, Former N.S.A. Translator, Gets More Than 5 Years in Leak of Russian Hacking Report |work=The New York Times}}</ref> Since her conviction, CTR has joined with many other organizations to call for Winner’s pardon or the commuting of her sentence to time served.
== Immigrants == CTR’s most recent campaign opposes the use of U.S. military personnel in immigrant detention camps and along U.S. borders. They have produced materials encouraging soldiers to resist what they call “illegal” orders in relation to immigration and they have supported GIs who have publically resisted. For example, they support U.S. Army Captain Brittany DeBarros who has used social media and other public statements to voice her opposition to the military’s immigrant related deployments. She stated, “I didn’t take an oath to defend illegal war abroad and immigrant concentration camps at home. True leaders refuse illegal and immoral orders.”<ref>{{cite web |url=https://couragetoresist.org/open-letter-border/ |title=OPEN LETTER TO ACTIVE DUTY SOLDIERS ON THE BORDER |date=2018-11-15 |last=Fanning |first=Former U.S. Army Ranger Rory |last2=Rapone |first2=Former U.S. Army Ranger and Infantry Officer Spenser |publisher=Courage To Resist |access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/brittany.ramos.940 |title=Brittany DeBarros |access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref>[[File:Courage to Resist Refuse Illegal Orders Campaign.jpg|thumb|center|300px|Image from the Courage to Resist campaign to encourage soldiers to refuse illegal anti-immigrant orders.]]

No Sir!]]'', a documentary about the anti-war movement within the ranks of the United States Armed Forces * [[Vietnam Veterans Against the War]] * [[List of anti-war organizations]] * [[List of peace activists]] * [[War Resisters League]]<ref>[http://www.warresisters.org/ War Resisters League]</ref> * [[Central Committee for Conscientious Objectors]]
